content.body: hrm
it's not clear how to proceed on the <device> thing until we have a codec
Oh, I wanted to link roc to <https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=535043>.  Oh well.
fantasai: Interesting. Al the documentation seems to have vanished
Still in svn though: http://html5lib.googlecode.com/svn/wiki/UserDocumentation.wiki
I wonder if we are supposed to migrate it to mercurial somehow
gsnedders: do we really need contentModelFlags.test to support initializing the tokenizer to an arbitrary?
gsnedders: also, what's spec for initialStates?
whew. the failures went away when I fixed the test harness to use the new test case syntax
except a couple of real failures I had introduces in the tokenizer
hg outgoing says
(deprecated '%' in path default-push=https://hsivonen%%40iki.fiâŠ™hgc/hg/ from /Users/Shared/Projects/html5lib/.hg/hgrc:3)
should I take one of the % signs away?
apparently, yes
hi
The W3C should really do whatever is needed to update WebIDL under /TR/
I am here to learn
it's not really up to the W3C
more up to weinig
I thought the whole purpose of /TR/ was for hosting outdated documents
Doesn't there have to be some sort of group decision or so?
mia^^: welcome
Anyway having a draft that is greater then 1 year out of date under TR seems unusually poor (and would certainly faila per-document rather than per-group heartbeat requirement)
wonders what crazy UA sniffing WebKit and Opera are going to face when they try to implement <script defer>
hsivone thank you
bbs phone
mia^^: Anything in particular you are here to learn, or just trying to soak up the ambiance?
jgraham, the reason is that weinig wanted to update some more things before pushing out a new version
jgraham, based on TC39 comments or something
does ES5 standardize the IE @cc_on stuff/
wonders why the document.write in http://www.mnot.net/templates/hinclude.js runs in Gecko
annevk2: I would prefer "push early puish often" as a policy. The current situation confuses the hell out of e.g. Google
hsivonen: @cc_on?
jgraham: JScript conditional comments
No
hmm.
jgraham, sure, I'm just explaining the situation
Hixie, what if you invoke StreamRecorder.stop() several times? seems you get ever-larger file objects with the current text
Hixie, you might want file objects per fragment
http://dev.w3.org/2009/dap/camera/ looks quite ugly
Philip`: yt?
gsnedders: y
oops. sorry. It seems I broke one test I thought I was fixing. I'll push a fix shortly.
did we agree that we want foster-parented text nodes to coalesce?
hsivonen: I think we did but I'm not sure Hixie did
hmmkay. should I change the "excite me" test case now or later?
didn't think anyone apart from him and hsivonen was in that thread
_We_ did. Dunno about anyone else.
Well I did too
I'll go ahead and change the test
is it intentional that we don't have a tree builder test file numbered 13?
lovely. I see test failures in script escapes and in the AAA
It used to exist, IIRC
hg log says it never did
gsnedders: if you wrote it, did you forget to hg add?
No
I didn't write it
I thought it had existed once
whoever wrote 14 must have assumed 13 existed
goes see where 14 came from
jgraham: blame points to you
I thought we once did and then it got moved to tests99 or so
But it could just have been a mistake :)
There were some tests that you made for not-yet-specified behaviour that got moved to a magic test file
airplanes skip row 13 too
it confused me recently
By "magic" I mean "numbered 99"
doesn't see a file numbered 99 in the repo
wonders if the list of bad numbers in the airplane row range has much more than 13 on it or if only skipping 13 is a culturally-biased thing and proper i18n would require skipping many more rows
Then that was spec'd and then it was moved
my script escape states are shamefully buggy
it's a small wonder they work for dogfooding in practice
I think if you skipped all the numbers that some culture considers unlucky you would have to go to a totally different system like named rows or something
ok if I change tests to anticipate Hixie fixing http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=8373 ?
jgraham, not sure that'd go down better :)
now I have only two classes of test case failures left:
1) surrogates (wontfix)
2) space characters in the AAA
doesn't like touching the AAA
also, we don't have enough test coverage for frameset-ok
surrogates?
annevk: the test cases test lone surrogates in JSON input
annevk: I've decided checking for those doesn't belong in the tokenizer
but belongs on a lower layer that doesn't participate with JSON
annevk3: i intend to make stop() make the object dead so a second call won't do anything
or might throw an exception
k
whoa, what's up with all the new accounts on wiki.whatwg.org?
changes topic to 'WHATWG: http://www.whatwg.org/ -- logs: http://krijnhoetmer.nl/irc-logs/ -- stats: http://gavinsharp.com/irc/whatwg.html -- Please leave your sense of logic at the door, thanks!'
i don't understand why people have such an adverse reaction to the websocket protocol spec
when probed, people always say it should be more like other specs, e.g. HTTP or the BWTP proposal, but that was exactly the kind of mistake I set out to avoid...
(mistake because those specs describe the wire protocol, but generally don't define client or server requirements, and don't define error handling)
Hixie, I think they are looking for a formal grammar describing WebSocket frames
Hixie, which, unless I am missing something, is not in the latest draft
what for?
Hixie, to understand and discuss the frame structure. FWIW, I also think you are right to precisely describe client and server requirements and error handling
without a grammar, you have to do a lot of reading to understand what the protocol would typically look like on the wire
well, there's a diagram in section 1.2 showing the wire format
but i guess i could add a non-normative abnf blob if that's what people want
That is only my best guess of what people want
judging from comments on hybi
huh. i don't think you can describe the wire protocol as ABNF.
uses the <> escape hatch
oh man
Forms WG comments are generating all the email
I guess we should just go the W3C way about this; make a WG decision to not address their comment and move on...
I mean sure, ideally everything would be separate and completely unreadable and even less understandable, but that's not the case
franksalim: well i tried adding some ABNF for the wire protocol, we'll see how that goes
Hixie, so to prevent the race condition I remove all currently queued tasks as part of the steps for abort()?
MacBook fail
I was planning on buying a new one but now this one is freezing/crashing on me all the time I'm not so sure anymore...
Have implementers said they don't want to implement any kind of fullscreen() API for video?
You'd think they could apply whatever heuristics they use for window.open().
For that matter, does Flash already allow scripts to fullscreen video?  If so, it doesn't seem to be abused much.
It at least allows them to make buttons that will trigger fullscreen.
the request was not for fullscreen video
at least not this time around
Oh, dear, I was totally misreading it.
Wait, he really does want fullscreen video.
Just he thinks you should be able to arbitrarily fullscreen pages.
That seems unnecessary.
Michael Dale is the one who works on video for Wikimedia, so I figured he was asking something about video.
anyway, bedtimes
Night.
annevk3: yeah i guess that'd be one way (so long as you only pull the tasks for this xhr)
